awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2018 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Anastasia M. Chavez is "Stochastic and Classical Matroid Theory". The host institution for the fellowship is the University of California, Davis, and the sponsoring scientist is Jesus De Loera.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: The goal of this project is to bridge together the pure and applied sides of matroid theory. The PI explored topics that investigated computational and probabilistic questions from a matroid perspective, as well as pure matroid questions with a computational flavor. From this emerged three major projects: 1) exploring graphical matroid structures via undirected graphs, 2) combinatorially characterizing quotients of positroids (i.e. flags of positroids), and 3) exploring a novel Catalan matroid object involving computational methods. The last project was completed as part of an undergraduate senior thesis for which the PI was the main advisor. 

In project 1, we proved structural results for the lattice generated by the cycles of an undirected graph, defined as the integer linear combinations of the 0/1-incidence vectors of cycles. We proved structural results for this lattice, including explicit formulas for its dimension and determinant, and presented efficient algorithms to construct lattice bases, using only cycles as generators, in quadratic time. By algebraic considerations, we related these results to the more general setting with coefficients from an arbitrary Abelian group. Our results generalize classical results for the vector space of cycles of a graph over the binary field to the case of an arbitrary field. 

In project 2, we combinatorially described the family of matroids that form quotients with the uniform matroid, that is, flag positroids. Motivated by the result that positively oriented matroids are realizable, our results work towards addressing the realizability of flag positively oriented matroids. Our results provide a novel circuit description for some positroids, as well as introduce the poset of positroid quotients. 

In project 3, with the PI acting as advisor to an undergraduate thesis, we studied a particular poset of matroid bases arising from Unit Interval Positroids (UIP), objects enumerated by the Catalan numbers. We showed one such poset arising from the family of externally ordered UIP bases can be described recursively. Explicitly, we describe an algorithm for constructing the lattice of a rank-n UIP from the lattice of lower ranks. Using their inherent combinatorial structure, we define a formula to enumerate the bases for a given UIP. 

Broader Impact: The findings from these projects have been presented at various national and international mathematical conferences, and published in academic journals. Several projects were international collaborations, and two directly supported the academic advancement of underrepresented students. Additionally, this award supported the PI in contributing to a variety of minority-serving projects.
